website_summaries.verdict: Don't let the size or build fool you – this portable model produces amazing sound.
pros: Earns praise for producing crisp, clean sound without background noise
cons: The housing doesn't have a very durable feel, but this doesn't affect the quality of its sound mixing capabilities

customer_reviews.title: or any annoying hissing. I am very satisfied with my purchase
customer_reviews.text: I needed something to mix audio from several sources and have separate outputs for headphones and an external amp. This fit the bill perfectly. May of the other mixers I looked at appear to be more appropriate for a studio type use, but this unit is very appropriate for my desktop given it's small size of 7" x 5.25" x 1.25, the placement of inputs/outputs, and the use of convenient and compact 3.5mm stereo connectors to minimize the bulk of cabling going to from the unit. Clipping indicators help to keep the levels in check. I did not notice any sound degradation when using this unit, or any annoying hissing. I am very satisfied with my purchase.
customer_reviews.author: R. Gagnier

customer_reviews.title: turn devices, iPhones, smartphones, tablets, and more into instruments
customer_reviews.text: That's what I do... you can see me on youtube creating live music with this thing and a usb hub connected to an iPad Pro and Zoom h6. I run my guitars and mics through the h6 and then I send the LOOP MIXER into the stereo in (channels 1 & 2). My iPhones, Mate 9 (android), and iPad which are connected to the LOOP MIXER become electronic instruments for tweaking sounds and creating synth and so much more.... and for live looping or live music production this is just so much FUN!
customer_reviews.author: Matthew John Armstron

customer_reviews.title: Very clean signal
customer_reviews.text: This is a great little mixer. I use it for processing audio from synthesizers, samplers, and drum machines. The signal is very clean. I originally bought it to add a few more stereo channels to my set up, by running it through a 12 channel mixer. I have tested the Loop Mixer bypassing my other mixer and directly connecting it to my audio interface. The signal is much cleaner then my 12 channel mixer. I'm very impressed, with the Loop Mixer, and over all completely satisfied. It is a great addition to my setup and I hope to see more products from this maker.
customer_reviews.author: Synth-freak

customer_reviews.title: I bought 2 and I'm thrilled with them
customer_reviews.text: I bought one with the loop bus cable so I could connect them. They sound perfect to my ears. I love that the channels are stereo. I love having a gain control for every channel. I love having the included adapter to connect a low-z instrument like an electric guitar. But the loop bus is where the magic happens for me. The loop bus duplicates each channel in the other mixer(s). It allows me to use one mixer to determine how much of each instrument to send to an effect, like reverb. The other mixer accepts the stereo output of the reverb unit and sets the "dry" level of each instrument. As I say, I'm thrilled with the results.
customer_reviews.author: Robert M Fowler

customer_reviews.title: Great little mixer
customer_reviews.text: It's a very sweet little thing. For it's size, 5 stereo channels is kind of unbelievable. I have 4 sources hooked up to it. Nice features, great sound quality. I'm just a wee bit disappointed in the DM2 adapter that came with it. When 1/4" cables are hooked up to it, it gets very heavy, and the connection is not very strong at the mixer for the weight. Any movement causes shorting with the speakers. Very loud. Get yourself a better quality adapter, use it only on a flat surface, or tape it down to something to support it. Everything else about this mixer for the price is stellar.
customer_reviews.author: Sunsinger

customer_reviews.title: Great, simple sound mixer with one flaw
customer_reviews.text: My only complaint with this mixer is the loud pop it generates when you turn it on. You must power off all downstream amps before you power this on! It could damage downstream amps if you do not. I use this to mix the sound output of multiple computers, so I power the mixer with the same UPS that all the computers use. This prevents the power-on pop from damaging my amp when utility power fails. I haven't found any other options for 3.5mm mixers, so this is really all there is.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Works great for a small, portable synth setup
customer_reviews.text: I took a chance on this after reading some reviews and watching video reviews on YouTube (I recommend watching the video by Ricky Tinez for an in-depth review). I think it works and sounds amazing for the price. I hooked up a Novation Circuit, Roland SE-02, and Arturia MicroFreak to it and everything sounded pretty good. Yes, it's plastic-y and probably won't stand up to a ton of physical abuse, but I don't think you can find a better 5 channel stereo mixer at this price point. I recommend it.
customer_reviews.author: Charles

customer_reviews.title: Great compact mixer
customer_reviews.text: Very nice little mixer. Super compact with good functionality and headphone output level. I use it to mix various devices including digital piano, ipad, yamaha THR10c, etc and it seems to work very well. Super nice packaging too, including power supply and 1/8" stereo to dual 1/4" in/outs. I haven't seen anything else on the market that compares with it. A bargain!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Solid, flexible mixer.
customer_reviews.text: I use this for multiple computers, mobile devices, etc, into a single set of speakers and it works great. The boost dials work well for low volume output devices and there are distortion indicator lights on it as well. Individual volume for headphone and speaker out is also nice. My only 2 complaints are that the plastic its made of doesnt feel as solid as i'd want And when the headphones are plugged in, the speaker output is still on so you need to turn off the volume for the speaker. Otherwise its great. Had it about 3 months and i never turn it off.
customer_reviews.author: EF

customer_reviews.title: A great mixer.
customer_reviews.text: This is a great little mixer. Sound quality is superb. It's lightweight and has a small footprint. It's multiple ouput options, for me, are a huge plus. Currently, I'm using the maker hart to route all my synths to another mixing console for guitar, mic, and drum machines. That way I can run my whole setup to my loop pedal and easily control the mix. Honestly though, i can think of any number of applications to use this mixer for. All in all couldn't be happier with the maker hart mixer.
customer_reviews.author: Danny j

customer_reviews.title: Left audio channel is distorted after ~2 years
customer_reviews.text: Been using this mixer for two years. Does its intended job decently. Can split numerous devices into one output or monitor. Biggest problem though, is that the left audio channel is distorted through the headphone out, resulting in a really prevalent crackling sound at any audio peaks. Maybe it's my own hearing, but whenever audio is actually at an acceptable/"hear-able" level, this crackling is produced. In other words, I find that this mixer produces a really low audio signal compared to just plugging a headset directly to your device. Adjusting anything, whether from the connected device or on the mixer itself, results in horrible quality audio.
customer_reviews.author: Brenden

customer_reviews.title: Everything the amateur musician needs.
customer_reviews.text: I don't expect to use the "loop" ports, but it has plenty else that I expect to use all the time, such as separate record, monitor and headphone outputs with volume controls for the latter two and a very useful 1/4" to 3.5mm microphone adapter accessory. The only possible limitation for people with a lot of instruments with stereo output is the 5 stereo inputs, although up to 10 mono inputs can be connected using mono-stereo adapters (not included) and mixed using the balance dials.
customer_reviews.author: Shimron Elit

customer_reviews.title: Perfect my 4 devices on my desk
customer_reviews.text: I have 4 devices on my desk connected by a KVM. However, I didn't want to lose audio as I switched between my devices. If I'm looking at one screen, and someone IMs me on another, I want to hear the sound. This device allows that. It works pretty well. The overload lights are useful as well to detect when you're pushing it too hard and need to adjust the mix.
customer_reviews.author: Berling

customer_reviews.title: works great, and most important does not add "noise" into ...
customer_reviews.text: I wanted this for a amateur guitar mixing studio using Logic, Garage Band, and Mainstage with my guitar. It is simple, works great, and most important does not add "noise" into the system. Not for pros, but absolutely great for under a hundred rather than a thousand.
customer_reviews.author: Sharon Tachenko

customer_reviews.title: Works Perfectly
customer_reviews.text: I love it when a product does exactly what it says it will do. Such is the case with the Maker Hart Loop Mixer. It seamlessly bridges my electric bass with my Sony TV with my Sennheiser headphones so I can practice my bass guitar along with my collection of concert DVDs. There's no distortion, no ground loop feedback, and the Loop Mixer provides me with independent volume control running to my stereo phones. As far as I'm concerned, a good job all the way around, Maker Hart!
customer_reviews.author: Paul J. Kledzik

customer_reviews.title: Multiple computers to one set of speakers
customer_reviews.text: I have 3 computers on my home office desk and wanted the ability to use one set of speakers or headphones for all computers/sound sources. This mixer worked perfectly. I was able to hook up all my computers and adjust levels for each source. The mixer is super compact and has a great look to it on my desk. I have already recommended this mixer to a few others that were in the same situation I was in.
customer_reviews.author: Cody Deschenes

customer_reviews.title: Simple mixer - pop/voltage spike in headphone jack during power-on
customer_reviews.text: I wanted a simple desk mixer without microphone pre-amps, with an on/off button, and that wasn't exceedingly expensive. This product hits all those boxes. Honestly I would have preferred 1/4" inputs over 1/8" inputs but I'll take what I can get. Only problem is the voltage spike through the front headphone jack when turning it on (loud pop/spike in headphones). Supposedly this can be damaging to headphones so I always unplug them before turning it on, but at this price I think this is the best you can do.
customer_reviews.author: Ion Dune

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for what I needed.
customer_reviews.text: I have three PCs and an Xbox one. I wanted to channel all the sounds from all devices into one PC so I can use one set of headphones for all. This does the job perfectly. Three inputs, one output, just what I needed. I didn't really need all the different controls, but they don't hurt in any way.
customer_reviews.author: J. Alberts

customer_reviews.title: Very decently surprised with the quality of this product
customer_reviews.text: I just received this earlier today and plugged in a few synthesizers and sound modules into it (this will be used for music purposes) and was pleasantly surprised to hear very little noise (I wasn't expecting this to be of great quality due to the price). The build quality is sturdy for a sub-$100 mixer and the controls are straightforward and for my basic use, very adequate. I had considered the Bastl dude mini mixer that was just released earlier this summer but this seems to be better in terms of i/o options. If they ever turn this into an audio interface in the future I'm sure they'd get a lot of buyers.

I have no issue with attenuation but am only driving a pair of headphones....

customer_reviews.title: This thing is a lifesaver! I have my PC ...

customer_reviews.title: Heads-up if you're connecting 3.5 mm microphones!
customer_reviews.text: Seems to do the job. I'm using it for recording multi-person interviews, connecting up to 5 lavalier mics (3.5 mm jacks). Here's a heads-up that I didn't anticipate though! If you're going to be using a lavalier mic, make sure that you have a mic that has a frequency response above 60 Hz (for example, at 65 Hz). Why?! Because if your mic can pick up 60 Hz frequencies (in US) or 50 Hz frequencies (in Europe), you're going to get buzzing sound. So unfortunately I can't use the $30 ATR3350. Instead, I'll be using the $50 ns-dlmic10p
